description:
Colletotrichum abscissum is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Colletotrichum, which is known to cause anthracnose diseases in various plant species. Colletotrichum abscissum is specifically associated with causing anthracnose on citrus fruits, such as oranges, lemons, and limes.

The fungus is characterized by the production of dark-colored, cylindrical to elliptical conidia (asexual spores) that are typically produced within acervuli (specialized fungal fruiting structures) on the surface of infected plant tissues. The conidia are dispersed by water, wind, or mechanical means, and can infect the plant through various entry points, such as wounds or natural openings.

Colletotrichum abscissum is known to cause characteristic symptoms on citrus fruits, including sunken, circular lesions that can lead to fruit drop and reduced fruit quality. The fungus can also infect other parts of the plant, such as leaves and stems, leading to further disease development and potential yield losses.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of Colletotrichum abscissum is crucial for the development of effective management strategies to control anthracnose in citrus production systems.
